title: 107_hr1509
content: The Act titled "National Media Campaign to Prevent Underage Drinking Act of 2001" amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national media campaign aimed at preventing underage drinking. The Secretary is required to conduct a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the United States based on scientific research and in consultation with the Surgeon General. The Secretary will implement a national media campaign based on research to reduce underage drinking in the United States, coordinating with various entities and federal agencies. The Secretary will coordinate with various Federal agencies and departments for a national media campaign targeting prevention and treatment resources for consumers in specific geographic areas, with language-appropriate messages for minority groups. The Secretary will ensure a national media campaign targeting prevention and treatment resources for consumers in specific geographic areas, with language-appropriate messages for minority groups. The campaign will devote sufficient funds to advertising to meet reach and frequency goals. The national media campaign will use funds for developing a comprehensive strategy, purchasing media time and space, talent reuse payments, advertising production costs, testing and evaluation, and assessing effectiveness. Funds under subsection (e) can be used for out-of-pocket advertising production costs, testing, evaluation of advertising effectiveness, and negotiated fees for winning bidders. Additionally, funds may support partnerships with community, civic, and professional groups for the media campaign. Funds under subsection (e) can be used for partnerships with community, civic, and professional groups, government organizations, and entertainment industry collaborations for underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats. The text chunk discusses the use of funds for underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats, including television programming, popular music, interactive media projects, public information, news media outreach, and corporate sponsorship. Prohibitions include not supplanting community-based efforts, pro bono public service time, partisan political purposes, or funding media campaigns featuring elected officials. The text chunk outlines prohibitions on the use of funds for media campaigns related to underage-drinking prevention, including restrictions on partisan political purposes, featuring elected officials, and displaying corporate logos. Additionally, a matching requirement is imposed for non-Federal contributions to the national media campaign. Reports to Congress are also required. The Secretary must develop and submit a comprehensive strategy to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the section, outlining the nature of underage drinking, scientific basis, target audiences, campaign goals, message points, implementation plan, and evaluation plan. The Secretary is required to submit annual reports to Congress on the activities related to underage drinking prevention, including details on the national media campaign's performance and costs. Additionally, a progress report must be submitted within one year of the strategy's implementation.
